name: Jumparound
description:
Game Title: Jump Around"Prototype"

iOS/Android/Tablet

Target age: young kids-Teens-Young adults

ESRB: E

Game Summary: Jump Around is a simple game that just uses the arrow keys for the use, all you do is jump around and dodge the items flown by. But there’s a catch The longer you play the game the more items will start flying in your direction from both sides and it’ll become harder for you to dodge them. So basically it starts off slow but it’ll gradually become faster to the point that there wont be any success at the end, because it’s to see how long you can survive for.

Game outline: it’s simple you’re a figure of some kind that is just on a simple map, nothing too crazy. You start off being able to jump around to get a feel for it then it’ll tell you that it’s starting. As soon as it’s starting the game, the objects will begin to come across from both sides of the map. There wouldn’t be too much to add to the game, maybe some percs you could acquire randomly on the game that would slow down the objects for a period of time when they come in faster. Also maybe a perc that clears the map of all objects giving that sense of relief for a little bit before they start flying again. The goal is to be simple yet a challenging game.

USP:

- Figure that jumps around.

- Objects fly across both sides of the map.

- don’t stop jumping

- survive

inspiration/ similar games

Flappy Bird/ Crossy Roads

Edit to the game:Jump around is a simple prototype that I came up with where the object of the game is simple. You jump around and dodge the enemies randomly flying around with a health system of 3. I know how it says points, don't pay any attention to that it would most likely be added when going back to it for making the game a little more interesting. I ended up putting an enemy that does higher damage than the other one so it should be easier to spot out and hopefully it works. Over all you just need to survive and have fun..good luck.  Original document is still the same, this is just an added on description to the prototype.
